node.excerpt: Google API blog announced today, new features for their Documents List ‚Äì Data APIs (DLDA) ‚Äì one of which is Optical Character Recognition(OCR). To put it simpy, sending an image(with readable text) to a DLDA application, when OCR is enabled into the request, will equip the API to read the image and generate a properly editable document.
node.html:
Google API blog announced today, new features for their Documents List ‚Äì Data APIs (DLDA) ‚Äì one of which is Optical Character Recognition(OCR). To put it simpy, sending an image(with readable text) to a DLDA application, when OCR is enabled into the request, will equip the API to read the image and generate a properly editable document.

Applied Fiction

Agent 007 photographed a top secret document he needs to deliver to M in CSV format (LOL). Q is not around to give him a nifty watch-slash-camera with OCR features. Good thing he also talks geek and plays with GoogleAPIs. He uploads the digital image into Google Docs and after a length of a blink, he gets a text version of the document. M receives the document, sends Bond a beautiful accountant to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù him, found the location of the villain, saves the world ‚Äì the end.

summary: 007:The Gold Potato that Never Dies Tomorrow


_Oh, I forgot he gets to trash another Aston Martin while saving the girl(not the accountant).
_
OCR is not integrated into Google Docs Home interface yet, but this API improvement is a step closer. Heres, a mockup of how I believe this feature would integrate into Google Docs‚Äôs upload function.

The feature is still in its early stages, shown by errors and misses in documents generated by the live demo. The developers did say to use high quality images.

OCR will only work well on high-resolution images. The quality of the extracted text isn‚Äôt perfect yet, but we‚Äôre busy improving it!

Miss or not, this is all very exciting, especially for Google Doc users like myself.

source: http://googledataapis.blogspot.com/2009/09/import-scans-or-go-multilingual.html

frontmatter.title: OCR API on Google Docs(not yet)

node.excerpt: Project 10^100 is a Google Project that transcends the information superhighway. It‚Äôs aim, simply, is to help ‚Äì to help people so they can help others. How ? They promised to give 10 million dollars to fund any project that can improve peoples lives. But as funding is finite, they need to find the best ideas.
node.html:
Project 10^100 is a Google Project that transcends the information superhighway. It‚Äôs aim, simply, is to help ‚Äì to help people so they can help others. How ? They promised to give 10 million dollars to fund any project that can improve peoples lives. But as funding is finite, they need to find the best ideas. Projects they believe, can do the most good.

The past year (2008), Google received more than 150,000 ideas. It took another year(2009) and 3000 Google employees to sort them through. The ideas need to cover one of the following categories

Categories:

  • Community: How can we help connect people, build communities and protect unique cultures?
  • Opportunity: How can we help people better provide for themselves and their families?
  • Energy: How can we help move the world toward safe, clean, inexpensive energy?
  • Environment: How can we help promote a cleaner and more sustainable global ecosystem?
  • Health: How can we help individuals lead longer, healthier lives?
  • Education: How can we help more people get more access to better education?
  • Shelter: How can we help ensure that everyone has a safe place to live?
  • Everything else: Sometimes the best ideas don‚Äôt fit into any category at all.

Out of the huge collection of ideas, they have narrowed them down to 16. Each of which is inspired by different submissions. So no one submission can claim the idea, just part of the whole. Its a wonder how some minds are alike. üôÇ Even greater wonder that they choose to do good with those creative brains.

What now?!

Now they are asking for people to vote. To pick the ideas they believe can make the difference. Out of 16 they need 5 ideas to turn into funded projects. The call to vote started September 24, 2009 and will end October 8, 2009. Watch this video:

So I invite you guys to go on Project 10^100‚Äôs voting page. Read all the ideas, and look into yourself what you think will help this hurting world of ours. Then pick the best one. After that invite others( friends,family, co-workers etc.) to do the same.

Conclusion

It‚Äôs great that large companies like Google still have that sense of civic responsibility to better this world. I hope this generation can nurture what Google started and the projects that will win this opportunity. God bless us all!

node.excerpt: Google released Picasa 3.5 yesterday, with some cool features. In keeping with Picasa Web Albums enhancements, ¬†Developers have added face recognition and geo tags to their photo-organizer-slash-jack-of-all-trades software.
node.html:
Google released Picasa 3.5 yesterday, with some cool features. In keeping with Picasa Web Albums enhancements, ¬†Developers have added face recognition and geo tags to their photo-organizer-slash-jack-of-all-trades software.

http://picasa-readme.blogspot.com/

With name tags, you can organize your photos based on what matters most: the people in them

As soon as the announcement came, I installed Picasa 3.5 ‚Äì eager to try the new features. As it seems, face recognition is activated from start , no warning whatsoever, but you do need to login to your picasa account to get your name tags.

Processing seems a bit longer than usual, as with the old version, you can still use the application even while it‚Äôs still sorting through all your stuff ‚Äì so no worries. Picasa 3.5 got almost 100% from my tests. I already tagged faces on Web Albums so I didn‚Äôt had the chance to tag new faces. But I‚Äôm amazed how good this works even if the person is facing front or showing their profile. Nevertheless, your results may vary depending on how distinct people in your photos are. If it‚Äôs anything like Picasa Web Albums, the engine should improve in time the more you use it.

Its a great addition to Picasa. It eases the pain of digging all your albums to find people. I know I‚Äôll be abusing this one for a long time. üôÇ

Download Picasa 3.5
Image from http://parenting.leehansen.com

node.excerpt: Google announced recently in its official blog, that it has acquired reCAPTCHA. CAPTCHA is a web technology made out of necessity. It primarily is used to prevent BOTS (or automated apps designed to do malicious tasks) by adding an extra step to site pages that require human interaction.
node.html:
Google announced recently in its official blog, that it has acquired reCAPTCHA. CAPTCHA is a web technology made out of necessity. It primarily is used to prevent BOTS (or automated apps designed to do malicious tasks) by adding an extra step to site pages that require human interaction. Yes, they‚Äôre the annoying barely readable text images when you register/login for a site.

Anyway, this move by Google is more than just for improving it‚Äôs CAPTCHA capabilities. As they explain, reCAPTCHA technology will improve Google projects that require reading text in images. The best to benefit from this are¬†Google‚Äôs ¬†Books project and the recent Fast Flip zine search. For more info see the official announcement.
